commit_message:
Cleanup multipath ISCSI connections when disconnecting volumes

The cleanup code previously would leave behind multipath entries and
did not always logout of the ISCSI portal. This back-ports the latest
stable/liberty multipath disconnect code from os-brick.

There are a number of changes partially cherry-picked/squashed into this
from both Cinder and finally os-brick (where they ended up).

Change-Id's from Cinder:
I65c93f3788020c944db0d3a55063a6415554ff11
I79c9627e9b47127d3765fcec5b7e3bacef179630

Change-Id's from os-brick:
I7a57687cac311c5e53361ccbceb1addb419f1e9f
I59bf37a932acd97cf915d086b4072b71e8214936
I1e5e9eba58a349509e80654ab3058c4ff5d00c0d
I8708db16a4b9057b09abad9f956fa5a3bb4ba54c
https://github.com/openstack/os-brick/commit/4f4ced7d8ff1c043065091771c2a8c9d69161d96

The above changes include fixes relating to the following bugs:
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1266048
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1375946
https://bugs.launchpad.net/ironic/+bug/1324670
https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1380742
https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1433204
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1456480
https://bugs.launchpad.net/os-brick/+bug/1483326

The best comparison though is to just look at the stable/liberty
os-brick connector code and compare with whats in volume.py. This change
is really just syncing the two.

Change-Id: I88ee8108d94ff0de162e7a1ca4152dfd59037cc5
Closes-Bug: #1385798
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/52/229152/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MULTIPATH_ERROR_REGEX = re.compile("\w{3} \d+ \d\d:\d\d:\d\d \|.*$") MULTIPATH_DEV_CHECK_REGEX = re.compile("\s+dm-\d+\s+") MULTIPATH_PATH_CHECK_REGEX = re.compile("\s+\d+:\d+:\d+:\d+\s+") self._rescan_multipath() device_realpath = os.path.realpath(host_device) self._remove_multipath_device(device_realpath) # flush any outstanding IO first self._flush_device_io(device_path) def _remove_multipath_device(self, multipath_name): """This removes LUNs associated with a multipath device and the multipath device itself. """ LOG.debug("remove multipath device %s" % multipath_name) mpath_dev = self._find_multipath_device(multipath_name) if mpath_dev: devices = mpath_dev['devices'] LOG.debug("multipath LUNs to remove %s" % devices) for device in devices: self._delete_device(device['device']) self._remove_multipath_device_descriptor(mpath_dev['id']) def _flush_device_io(self, device): """This is used to flush any remaining IO in the buffers.""" try: LOG.debug("Flushing IO for device %s" % device) utils.execute('blockdev', '--flushbufs', device, run_as_root=True) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: msg = _("Failed to flush IO buffers prior to removing" " device: (%(code)s)") % {'code': exc.exit_code} LOG.warn(msg) def _find_multipath_device(self, device): """Find a multipath device associated with a LUN device name. device can be either a /dev/sdX entry or a multipath id. """ mdev = None devices = [] out = None try: (out, err) = self._run_multipath(['-l', device], check_exit_code=[0, 1]) except processutils.ProcessExecutionError as exc: LOG.warn(_("multipath call failed exit (%(code)s)") % {'code': exc.exit_code}) return None if out: lines = out.strip() lines = lines.split("\n") lines = [line for line in lines if "scsi_id" not in line] # ignore udev errors if lines: line = lines[0] info = line.split(" ") # device line output is different depending # on /etc/multipath.conf settings. if info[1][:2] == "dm": mdev = "/dev/%s" % info[1] mdev_id = info[0] elif info[2][:2] == "dm": mdev = "/dev/%s" % info[2] mdev_id = info[1].replace('(', '') mdev_id = mdev_id.replace(')', '') if mdev is None: LOG.warn(_("Couldn't find multipath device %(line)s") % {'line': line}) return None LOG.debug("Found multipath device = %(mdev)s" % {'mdev': mdev}) device_lines = lines[3:] for dev_line in device_lines: if dev_line.find("policy") != -1: continue dev_line = dev_line.lstrip(' |-`') dev_info = dev_line.split() address = dev_info[0].split(":") dev = {'device': '/dev/%s' % dev_info[1], 'host': address[0], 'channel': address[1], 'id': address[2], 'lun': address[3] } devices.append(dev) if mdev is not None: info = {"device": mdev, "id": mdev_id, "devices": devices} return info return None def _get_multipath_device_map(self): out = self._run_multipath(['-ll'], check_exit_code=[0, 1])[0] mpath_line = [line for line in out.splitlines() if not re.match(MULTIPATH_ERROR_REGEX, line)] mpath_dev = None mpath_map = {} for line in out.splitlines(): m = MULTIPATH_DEV_CHECK_REGEX.split(line) if len(m) >= 2: mpath_dev = '/dev/mapper/' + m[0].split(" ")[0] continue m = MULTIPATH_PATH_CHECK_REGEX.split(line) if len(m) >= 2: mpath_map['/dev/' + m[1].split(" ")[0]] = mpath_dev if mpath_line and not mpath_map: LOG.warn(_LW("Failed to parse the output of multipath -ll.")) return mpath_map mpath_map = self._get_multipath_device_map() if os.path.exists(dev): if "/mapper/" in dev: devices.append(dev) else: mpdev = mpath_map.get(dev) if mpdev: devices.append(mpdev) LOG.info('patrickeast devices = ' + str(devices)) all_ips_iqns = self._get_target_portals_from_iscsiadm_output(out) # As discovery result may contain other targets' iqns, extract targets # to be disconnected whose block devices are already deleted here. entries = [device.lstrip('ip-').split('-lun-')[0] for device in self._get_iscsi_devices()] for ip, iqn in all_ips_iqns: if ip_iqn not in entries: ips_iqns.append([ip, iqn]) LOG.info('patrickeast ips_iqns = ' + str(ips_iqns)) LOG.info('patrickeast DISCONNECTING!!! (A)') other_iqns = self._get_multipath_iqns(devices, mpath_map) LOG.info('patrickeast other_iqns = ' + str(other_iqns)) LOG.info('patrickeast current_iqns = ' + str(current_iqns)) LOG.info('patrickeast in_use = ' + str(in_use)) LOG.info('patrickeast DISCONNECTING!!! (B)') except IndexError: LOG.info('patrickeast _get_iscsi_devices ERROR!!') LOG.info('patrickeast _get_iscsi_devices devices = ' + str(devices)) LOG.info('patrickeast _get_iscsi_devices entry = ' + str(entry)) def _get_multipath_iqns(self, multipath_devices, mpath_map): entries = self._get_iscsi_devices() iqns = [] for entry in entries: entry_real_path = os.path.realpath("/dev/disk/by-path/%s" % entry) entry_multipath = mpath_map.get(entry_real_path) if entry_multipath and entry_multipath in multipath_devices: iqns.append(entry.split("iscsi-")[1].split("-lun")[0]) return iqns
deleted_lines: self._rescan_iscsi() self._rescan_multipath() if "/mapper/" in dev: devices.append(dev) else: mpdev = self._get_multipath_device_name(dev) if mpdev: devices.append(mpdev) # Extract targets for the current multipath device. entries = self._get_iscsi_devices() for ip, iqn in self._get_target_portals_from_iscsiadm_output(out): for entry in entries: entry_ip_iqn = entry.split("-lun-")[0] if entry_ip_iqn[:3] == "ip-": entry_ip_iqn = entry_ip_iqn[3:] elif entry_ip_iqn[:4] == "pci-": # Look at an offset of len('pci-0000:00:00.0') offset = entry_ip_iqn.find("ip-", 16, 21) entry_ip_iqn = entry_ip_iqn[(offset + 3):] if (ip_iqn != entry_ip_iqn): continue entry_real_path = os.path.realpath("/dev/disk/by-path/%s" % entry) entry_mpdev = self._get_multipath_device_name(entry_real_path) if entry_mpdev == multipath_device: ips_iqns.append([ip, iqn]) break other_iqns = [self._get_multipath_iqn(device) for device in devices] return elif multipath_device not in devices: # delete the devices associated w/ the unused multipath self._delete_mpath(iscsi_properties, multipath_device, ips_iqns) # else do not disconnect iscsi portals, # as they are used for other luns, # just remove multipath mapping device descriptor self._remove_multipath_device_descriptor(multipath_device) except IndexError: def _delete_mpath(self, iscsi_properties, multipath_device, ips_iqns): entries = self._get_iscsi_devices() # Loop through ips_iqns to construct all paths iqn_luns = [] for ip, iqn in ips_iqns: iqn_lun = '%s-lun-%s' % (iqn, iscsi_properties.get('target_lun', 0)) iqn_luns.append(iqn_lun) for dev in ['/dev/disk/by-path/%s' % dev for dev in entries]: for iqn_lun in iqn_luns: if iqn_lun in dev: self._delete_device(dev) self._rescan_multipath()

commit_message:
Added webroot config to dashboard

1.add default dashboard_webroot config to all.yml
2.add dashboard_webroot config to globals.yml
  if someone wants to modify the value,
  he or she can modify this file
3.add dashboard_webroot reference to horizon.conf.j2
  and local_settings.j2

Change-Id: Ia89d317392ac87c5769814759fd6fc26fc77193c
Closes-Bug: #1570677

commit_message:
Updates PyKMIP version

PyKMIP version 0.2.0 breaks stable/kilo Barbican. The next version
that works is 0.3.3.

Change-Id: I7c82bab96e4a4155502bce83c921371ede5b0559
Closes-bug: 1451089

subject: libvirt: set libvirt.sysinfo_serial='none' for virt driver tests
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-01 21:29:19.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/8bb6af1240317f36f61539c12abecbbf1757cd62', 'message': "libvirt: set libvirt.sysinfo_serial='none' for virt driver tests

The default value for the sysinfo_serial option is 'auto' which
tries to read from the /etc/machine-id file if it exists and is
not empty.

Unit tests should not be dependent on trying to read from system
files outside the virtual environment, so for the generic virt
driver tests set the config option value to 'none' so we don't
do anything for the sysinfo_serial option.

Change-Id: Ib9ba0ec2c1690d93eadb63e699740e4ba988cce1
Closes-Bug: #1551900
(cherry picked from commit 6c3991e881312d715d08f94158d72f8c37dfc6a4)
(cherry picked from commit 2da1d8ba76b0041b71ef8f39f74e3d2330a4dc4d)
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-03-10 01:30:02.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/virt/test_virt_drivers.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/54ff59b0ad0d4be9ebcfaebcef7a2a30b287f367', 'message': "libvirt: set libvirt.sysinfo_serial='none' for virt driver tests

The default value for the sysinfo_serial option is 'auto' which
tries to read from the /etc/machine-id file if it exists and is
not empty.

Unit tests should not be dependent on trying to read from system
files outside the virtual environment, so for the generic virt
driver tests set the config option value to 'none' so we don't
do anything for the sysinfo_serial option.

Change-Id: Ib9ba0ec2c1690d93eadb63e699740e4ba988cce1
Closes-Bug: #1551900

commit_message:
libvirt: set libvirt.sysinfo_serial='none' for virt driver tests

The default value for the sysinfo_serial option is 'auto' which
tries to read from the /etc/machine-id file if it exists and is
not empty.

Unit tests should not be dependent on trying to read from system
files outside the virtual environment, so for the generic virt
driver tests set the config option value to 'none' so we don't
do anything for the sysinfo_serial option.

Change-Id: Ib9ba0ec2c1690d93eadb63e699740e4ba988cce1
Closes-Bug: #1551900
(cherry picked from commit 6c3991e881312d715d08f94158d72f8c37dfc6a4)
(cherry picked from commit 2da1d8ba76b0041b71ef8f39f74e3d2330a4dc4d)

subject: Only create volumes with instance.az if cinder.cross_az_attach is False
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-03 17:08:26.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/50364487560edd04944b32f41ab6bd0da3d85080', 'message': "Only create volumes with instance.az if cinder.cross_az_attach is False

Commit 6060888b58db42eea826939852838f9e1c204d2c changed the boot from
volume flow where source != 'volume' (where Nova creates the volume and
then attaches it to the instance during the server create operation)
such that the instance.availability_zone is always passed to the volume
create API.  That was done because if the cinder.cross_az_attach config
option is False then Nova requires the instance and volume AZs to be the
same when attaching the volume.

However, telling Cinder to create a volume based on the instance AZ can
fail if that AZ doesn't exist in Cinder.

Cinder commit b85d2812a8256ff82934d150dbc4909e041d8b31 works around this
by allowing Cinder to be configured to basically not fail if the
requested AZ does not exist. This is not a great solution though if you
have cinder.cross_az_attach=False in Nova because Cinder ignored your
request.  It's also terrible UX for the end user because they get a
NoValidHost when boot from volume fails.  There is a TODO in this change
to address that later (because exactly how cross-service AZs should work
is still being discussed).

This change addresses the gap introduced by always telling Cinder to
create the volume with the instance AZ.  We should only do that when
cinder.cross_az_attach is False, because that's the strict case where
Nova expects them to match.  If cross_az_attach is True, Nova doesn't
care what AZ the volume is in so we shouldn't try and force
Cinder to accommodate the Nova AZ when creating the volume.

Closes-Bug: #1496235

Change-Id: I3d60c084fd71162a0d4835394f8e819723c1b8a7
(cherry picked from commit f9a51b970f688b90baf0ae3ef31d79b3fec02ed1)

commit_message:
Only create volumes with instance.az if cinder.cross_az_attach is False

Commit 6060888b58db42eea826939852838f9e1c204d2c changed the boot from
volume flow where source != 'volume' (where Nova creates the volume and
then attaches it to the instance during the server create operation)
such that the instance.availability_zone is always passed to the volume
create API.  That was done because if the cinder.cross_az_attach config
option is False then Nova requires the instance and volume AZs to be the
same when attaching the volume.

However, telling Cinder to create a volume based on the instance AZ can
fail if that AZ doesn't exist in Cinder.

Cinder commit b85d2812a8256ff82934d150dbc4909e041d8b31 works around this
by allowing Cinder to be configured to basically not fail if the
requested AZ does not exist. This is not a great solution though if you
have cinder.cross_az_attach=False in Nova because Cinder ignored your
request.  It's also terrible UX for the end user because they get a
NoValidHost when boot from volume fails.  There is a TODO in this change
to address that later (because exactly how cross-service AZs should work
is still being discussed).

This change addresses the gap introduced by always telling Cinder to
create the volume with the instance AZ.  We should only do that when
cinder.cross_az_attach is False, because that's the strict case where
Nova expects them to match.  If cross_az_attach is True, Nova doesn't
care what AZ the volume is in so we shouldn't try and force
Cinder to accommodate the Nova AZ when creating the volume.

Closes-Bug: #1496235

Change-Id: I3d60c084fd71162a0d4835394f8e819723c1b8a7
(cherry picked from commit f9a51b970f688b90baf0ae3ef31d79b3fec02ed1)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/82/253082/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_config import cfgCONF = cfg.CONF CONF.import_opt('cross_az_attach', 'nova.volume.cinder', group='cinder') def _get_volume_create_az_value(instance): """Determine az to use when creating a volume Uses the cinder.cross_az_attach config option to determine the availability zone value to use when creating a volume. :param nova.objects.Instance instance: The instance for which the volume will be created and attached. :returns: The availability_zone value to pass to volume_api.create """ # If we're allowed to attach a volume in any AZ to an instance in any AZ, # then we don't care what AZ the volume is in so don't specify anything. if CONF.cinder.cross_az_attach: return None # Else the volume has to be in the same AZ as the instance otherwise we # fail. If the AZ is not in Cinder the volume create will fail. But on the # other hand if the volume AZ and instance AZ don't match and # cross_az_attach is False, then volume_api.check_attach will fail too, so # we can't really win. :) # TODO(mriedem): It would be better from a UX perspective if we could do # some validation in the API layer such that if we know we're going to # specify the AZ when creating the volume and that AZ is not in Cinder, we # could fail the boot from volume request early with a 400 rather than # fail to build the instance on the compute node which results in a # NoValidHost error. return instance.availability_zone av_zone = _get_volume_create_az_value(instance) av_zone = _get_volume_create_az_value(instance) av_zone = _get_volume_create_az_value(instance)
deleted_lines: av_zone = instance.availability_zone av_zone = instance.availability_zone av_zone = instance.availability_zone

commit_message:
Changed an HTTP exception to return proper code

POSTing to /servers with a content-type of text/plain
and a text/plain body results in a response code of 400.
It should be 415. I found this line in the code that
appears to handle this singular case and modified
the HTTP exception used to the correct one. Tests were
also updated accordingly.

Change-Id: I5fa1fdba56803b2ef63b1efaaeeced6ceb7779d9
Closes-Bug: 1567977
(cherry picked from commit a7019a87ba696509d825c6c6f2220331e4ffb033)

commit_message:
Soft delete instance group member when delete instance

Currently after instance deleted, the instance is still as member
of instance group. This patch make sure the instance will removed
from instance group when execute instance_destroy db call.

Closes-Bug: #1442098

Change-Id: I8cae3e5c317f0797944ecf3bea21c571ff24d9cf
(cherry picked from commit e2f4370b04598833939f2b869e7bac11c02a4921)

commit_message:
Fixed nits in the new inspection doc page

A follow-up to If5d466a2c331674abb30d30dc39871f25a84de88:
* Fixed list of drivers using in-band inspection
* Added missing introduction to the in-band inspection section
* Small formatting improvements

Change-Id: Ie640fbc2b4fbf936a6ba8666dc43b2cd5e6afcef
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/62/308862/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: list is provided by the iLO :ref:`ilo-inspection`. whether secure boot is supported for the node the boot mode the node is using whether the CPU virtualization is enabled whether the AES CPU extensions are enabled maximum RAID level supported by the node number of GPU devices on the nodeIn-band inspection involves booting a ramdisk on the target node and fetching information directly from it. This process is more fragile and time-consuming than the out-of-band inspection, but it is not vendor-specific and works across a wide range of hardware. In-band inspection is using the ironic-inspector_ project. Currently it is supported by the following generic drivers:: agent_ipmitool agent_ipminative agent_ssh fake_inspector It is also the default inspection approach for the following vendor drivers:: pxe_drac pxe_ucs pxe_cimc agent_ucs agent_cimc This feature needs to be explicitly enabled in the ironic configuration file
deleted_lines: list is provided by :ref:`ilo`. whether secure boot is supported for the node; the boot mode the node is using; whether the CPU virtualization is enabled; whether the AES CPU extensions are enabled; maximum RAID level supported by the node; number of GPU devices on the node.This is supported by the following drivers:: pxe_drac This feature needs to be explicitly enabled in the configuration

commit_message:
Add validations for volume_size and destination_type

Add validations for volume_size and destination_type of
block device mapping when creating an instance
in order to avoid HTTP 500 errors.
Validations has been added in V2.1 API only.
Validations that has been added are as follows:

* volume_size: an empty string
* volume_size: zero
* volume_size: greater than DB column's limit
* destination_type: an empty string
* destination_type: invalid value

Change-Id: I2d3084cccd15f409616031f106c611ff07ac4abf
Closes-Bug: #1525806

added_lines: def test_create_instance_with_destination_type_empty_string(self): self.bdm[0]['destination_type'] = '' old_create = compute_api.API.create def create(*args, **kwargs): self.assertEqual(kwargs['block_device_mapping'], self.bdm) return old_create(*args, **kwargs) self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'create', create) params = {block_device_mapping.ATTRIBUTE_NAME: self.bdm} self.assertRaises(self.validation_error, self._test_create, params, no_image=True) def test_create_instance_with_invalid_destination_type(self): self.bdm[0]['destination_type'] = 'fake' old_create = compute_api.API.create def create(*args, **kwargs): self.assertEqual(kwargs['block_device_mapping'], self.bdm) return old_create(*args, **kwargs) self.stubs.Set(compute_api.API, 'create', create) params = {block_device_mapping.ATTRIBUTE_NAME: self.bdm} self.assertRaises(self.validation_error, self._test_create, params, no_image=True)

commit_message:
[Common] Move code from utils.percentile to PercentileComputation

Function rally.task.processing.utils.percentile is actually used
only by rally.common.streaming_algorighms.PercentileComputation,
so better location for this function is streaming_algorighms.
Since we have plans to use only streaming computation for results
processing, the code is just embedded into
PercentileComputation.result().

Change-Id: I695f79f5ad3535ee281cc7af669d8bbbb76cdf2b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/95/304595/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def percentile(values, percent): """Find the percentile of a list of values. :parameter values: list of numbers :parameter percent: float value from 0.0 to 1.0 :returns: the percentile of values """ if not values: return None values.sort() k = (len(values) - 1) * percent f = math.floor(k) c = math.ceil(k) if f == c: return values[int(k)] d0 = values[int(f)] * (c - k) d1 = values[int(c)] * (k - f) return (d0 + d1) return percentile(results, self._percent)
deleted_lines: return utils.percentile(results, self._percent)

commit_message:
Enhance Tunnel Technologies section of Networking Guide

The current Tunnel Technologies section of the
Networking Guide needs to be expanded.

Closes-Bug: #1466559

Change-Id: I4f2a42486269d958cda4a95ee78b24b0454c34e3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/73/290073/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Tunneling Technologies Tunneling, also known as port forwarding or encapsulation is a mechanism that makes transfer of payload feasible over an incompatible delivery network. It allows the network user to gain access to another unpermitted or unsecure network. Here the packet is hidden within the IP datagram . Data encryption may be employed to transport the payload. This ensures that the encapsulated user network data appears as public even though it is private and can easily pass the adversary network. Generic Routing Encapsulation GRE GRE is a protocol that runs over IP, generally employed when delivery and payload protocols are compatible but payload addresses are incompatible. For instance a payload might think it is running on a datalink layer but, in actual running over transport layer using datagram protocol over IP. GRE creates a private point-to-point connection and works by encapsulating a payload. GRE is a foundation protocol for other tunnel protocols but the GRE tunnels provide only weak authentication. Virtual extensible local area network (VXLAN) Isolated networks present in Cloud Computing. VMware is used to duplicate the addresses of virtual machines for each instance of the application for the very purpose. So the purpose of VXLAN is to provide scalable network isolation.It is an encapusalation method to extend layer 2 traffic over layer 3 network. Basically VXLAN connects two or more layer 3 network domains and make them look like a common layer 2 domain, thereby allowing different VM communicate as if they are on a common layer 2 subnet. ~

commit_message:
Fix doc build if git is absent

When building packages if git is absent, then we should not set
html_last_updated_fmt. It can still be set via the -D switch
when building with sphinx-build.

Change-Id: I5da86b7a163c0e795cd34abf79b0980a8552f79b
Closes-Bug: #1552251
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/95/304995/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import warningstry: html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.Popen( git_cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0] except: warnings.warn('Cannot get last updated time from git repository. ' 'Not setting "html_last_updated_fmt".')
deleted_lines: html_last_updated_fmt = subprocess.Popen( git_cmd, stdout=subprocess.PIPE).communicate()[0]

commit_message:
Add ability to override network templace from InstanceMetadata

There was no way to fully exploited the template parameter of
netutils.get_injected_network_template within InstanceMetadata.

Overriding the network template could be useful for driver authors
which could require a different network template based on flavor or
individual instance properties.

The default behavior is not changed:
If template=None is passed, the default network template is used.

Closes-bug: #1449712
Change-Id: Ide9b1529632b1a262ffd20dddf8a8632d596db50
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/40/178340/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: network_info=None, vd_driver=None, template=None): cfg = netutils.get_injected_network_template( network_info, template=template)
deleted_lines: network_info=None, vd_driver=None): cfg = netutils.get_injected_network_template(network_info)

commit_message:
Change redstack to use default config values

The plugin code has been enhanced to allow configuration
of Trove using variables. The default there is to use the
actual config values in the Trove repsoitory. This has
been mirrored here, in that the variables are listed so
that a user/developer can modify them if they wish, but
they do not override the default values anymore.

The proper place to add these variables would be in a
'local' options file, such as options.rc or
~/.redstack.options.rc

Change-Id: I38bc7190f1c112b4ae3cd6614f1d6cb625b3387d
Depends-On: I2c568fdfa05064682f372b996a5aebcdd4e93ef3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove-integration refs/changes/63/301763/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # The following values can be used to tweak how devstack sets # up Trove. If not explicitly set, the defaults in the code are used. # To make changes without modifying the repo, add these variables # to options.rc or ~/redstack.options.rc #TROVE_AGENT_CALL_HIGH_TIMEOUT=300 #TROVE_RESIZE_TIME_OUT=900 #TROVE_USAGE_TIMEOUT=1500 #TROVE_STATE_CHANGE_WAIT_TIME=180 #TROVE_MAX_ACCEPTED_VOLUME_SIZE=10 #TROVE_MAX_INSTANCES_PER_TENANT=10 #TROVE_MAX_VOLUMES_PER_TENANT=40
deleted_lines: TROVE_AGENT_CALL_HIGH_TIMEOUT=${TROVE_AGENT_CALL_HIGH_TIMEOUT:-300} TROVE_RESIZE_TIME_OUT=${TROVE_RESIZE_TIME_OUT:-900} TROVE_USAGE_TIMEOUT=${TROVE_USAGE_TIMEOUT:-1500} TROVE_STATE_CHANGE_WAIT_TIME=${TROVE_STATE_CHANGE_WAIT_TIME:-180} # Set up quota values TROVE_MAX_ACCEPTED_VOLUME_SIZE=${TROVE_MAX_ACCEPTED_VOLUME_SIZE:-10} TROVE_MAX_INSTANCES_PER_USER=${TROVE_MAX_INSTANCES_PER_USER:-10} TROVE_MAX_VOLUMES_PER_USER=${TROVE_MAX_VOLUMES_PER_USER:-10}

subject: Make run_ofctl check for socket error
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-03-24 11:26:30.000000000', 'files': ['neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py', 'neutron/tests/unit/agent/common/test_ovs_lib.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/5390cc8af2dba69f3823fe8fdaffb579d528fe62', 'message': 'Make run_ofctl check for socket error

When the OVS bridge is still being initialized we get
a "failed to connect to socket" error when running ovs-ofctl.
This shows up quite frequently in our functional tests and
may be the source of their high failure rate.

Ultimately we need to change the behavior of run_ofctl to not
ignore errors by default, but this will require a lot of effort
because there are many places that likely expect this behavior.

As a workaround, this patch checks for the specific socket failure
and attempts the command again up to 10 times, sleeping for 1
second between each attempt to wait for the bridge to be ready.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py

Closes-Bug: #1550623
Closes-Bug: #1551593
Change-Id: I663a54608ed96133014104fe033ecea0a867ac4c
(cherry picked from commit a6c231cdd731dae900c372799a890407bbc24a2c)
(cherry picked from commit eec85f361ecd8af96c73d0c8ff1c9fb1d347220a)
'}]
commit_message:
Make run_ofctl check for socket error

When the OVS bridge is still being initialized we get
a "failed to connect to socket" error when running ovs-ofctl.
This shows up quite frequently in our functional tests and
may be the source of their high failure rate.

Ultimately we need to change the behavior of run_ofctl to not
ignore errors by default, but this will require a lot of effort
because there are many places that likely expect this behavior.

As a workaround, this patch checks for the specific socket failure
and attempts the command again up to 10 times, sleeping for 1
second between each attempt to wait for the bridge to be ready.

Conflicts:
	neutron/agent/common/ovs_lib.py

Closes-Bug: #1550623
Closes-Bug: #1551593
Change-Id: I663a54608ed96133014104fe033ecea0a867ac4c
(cherry picked from commit a6c231cdd731dae900c372799a890407bbc24a2c)
(cherry picked from commit eec85f361ecd8af96c73d0c8ff1c9fb1d347220a)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/35/297035/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_run_ofctl_retry_on_socket_error(self): err = RuntimeError('failed to connect to socket') self.execute.side_effect = [err] * 5 with mock.patch('time.sleep') as sleep: self.br.run_ofctl('add-flows', []) self.assertEqual(5, sleep.call_count) self.assertEqual(6, self.execute.call_count) # a regular exception fails right away self.execute.side_effect = RuntimeError('garbage') self.execute.reset_mock() with mock.patch('time.sleep') as sleep: self.br.run_ofctl('add-flows', []) self.assertEqual(0, sleep.call_count) self.assertEqual(1, self.execute.call_count)

commit_message:
Add variables for quota configuration

Many configuration values are hard-coded in the Trove devstack
plugin, however they would be better served letting the
user/developer decide what limits to impose.

The following variables were added to facilitate this:

TROVE_MAX_ACCEPTED_VOLUME_SIZE
TROVE_MAX_INSTANCES_PER_TENANT
TROVE_MAX_VOLUMES_PER_TENANT
TROVE_AGENT_CALL_LOW_TIMEOUT
TROVE_AGENT_CALL_HIGH_TIMEOUT
TROVE_RESIZE_TIME_OUT
TROVE_USAGE_TIMEOUT
TROVE_STATE_CHANGE_WAIT_TIME

These values are only inserted if they are set. If not set,
the Trove defaults are used instead.

Change-Id: I2c568fdfa05064682f372b996a5aebcdd4e93ef3

commit_message:
Log diskimage-builder output to a file

Currently the diskimage-builder output goes directly to
stdout/stderr. This is not good behavior for a library.

This patch changes that behavior to write this output to
a log file. (image_path/image_name.log)

Change-Id: I4047605893810088ff5fa3215781e39fff0cfbbd
Closes-Bug: 1577374
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/56/311756/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: log_file = '%s.log' % image_path with open(log_file, 'w') as log_fd: subprocess.check_call(cmd, stdout=log_fd, stderr=log_fd)
deleted_lines: subprocess.check_call(cmd)

commit_message:
Check flag to create public network and router

Currently devstack only creates an initial public network and
router if the neutron L3 agent is enabled.  This change allows a
devstack plugin (which maybe providing its own L3 implementation)
to set a flag to indicate that the public network and router should
be created.

Change-Id: I85930c564023e3e66c560f3747a5c19b9e24c8f8
Closes-Bug: #1567068

commit_message:
Prevent nova-api from dying if enabled_apis is wrong

This prevents nova-api from dying if there are values in
``enabled_apis`` which don't actually exist.

Closes-Bug: #1572495

Change-Id: Id9a6f5e38b017f4687eb245fd238104379d437d6
(cherry picked from commit 533bd8175968a1bc9ac068ae2b23a62d0e07ea99)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/312108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 HPE, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import mock from nova.cmd import api from nova import config from nova import test # required because otherwise oslo early parse_args dies @mock.patch.object(config, 'parse_args', new=lambda *args, **kwargs: None) class TestNovaAPI(test.NoDBTestCase): @mock.patch('nova.service.process_launcher') def test_with_ec2(self, launcher): """Ensure that we don't explode if enabled_apis is wrong. If the end user hasn't updated their config, an ec2 entry might accidentally kill them in starting up their server. This tests that our new safety filter will prevent that. The metadata api is excluded because it loads a bunch of the network stack, which requires other mocking. """ self.flags(enabled_apis=['ec2', 'osapi_compute']) # required because of where the portbind happens, so that we # collide on ports. self.flags(osapi_compute_listen_port=0) api.main()

commit_message:
Move away from invoking api tests explicitly

Since adoption of the Tempest plugin framework, this
extra plumbing is no longer necessary in tree.

Related-bug: 1555356

Depends-on: If5f7ea82c45494953452f728fabb7403d0b6e14e
Change-Id: I5377f33c5a7b29f97f00878e048d154378a4fe34

commit_message:
Update is_service_enabled

The nova check in is_service_enabled() is loading the nova repo
when ENABLED_SERVICES=ovn-northd.  Add a comma before each of the
checks to prevent this error with any of the other services.

Change-Id: I9deee735812cde44ea5140b1ad76848f02576609
Closes-Bug: #1574431

commit_message:
Remove tempest-lib setup

Tempest-lib, as a standalone project, is deprecated in favor of a
"lib/" directory inside Tempest's repo. So remove the installation
of tempest-lib in DevStack.

Change-Id: I507bfe875777fd25bbe5d67c861f3fca99faa22d

commit_message:
Remove deprecated references to g-search

Commit 020586fab4173ea860789e459cb941c85179c739 removed support
for g-search as it was promoted to its own project. The devstack
plugin for Searchlight triggers the installation of elasticsearch,
so it can be removed from upstream devstack.

Change-Id: Iada75fc59c66b776c506431f93deb668ab0a84b9

commit_message:
Explicitly specify firewall_driver in ml2_conf.ini file

When using the Open vSwitch Neutron agent, security groups will not
function if the firewall_driver configuration is not specified.

Change-Id: Ib9a476c2c99091fc82962c5f3853454843cbb804

commit_message:
Missing Grafana buttons

If GRAFAN_URL is not defined and GRAFANA_LINKS contains titles and
links for buttons they are rendered as a empty div with  border.
This commit fix that.

Change-Id: Icdc532210f26b6906c1650a06d7285d5b8a70735

commit_message:
Remove Manager Local Locks for HA A/A

This spec outlines work needed to remove local locks from Volume nodes.

Two methods are used, filters on the compare-and-swap mechanism and lock
mechanism using workers table.

This is one of the aspects that are needed to support Active/Active in
cinder.

Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Iab5bf8c3971d4a908bec16882fb4ca4a50c7dfdb
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/02/237602/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================= Cinder Volume Active/Active support - Manager Local Locks ============================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-volume-active-active-support Right now cinder-volume service can run only in Active/Passive HA fashion. One of the reasons for this is that we have multiple **local locks** in the Volume nodes for mutual exclusion of specific operations on the same resource. These locks need to be shared between nodes of the same cluster, removed or replaced with DB operations. This spec proposes different mechanism to replace these local locks. Problem description =================== We have locks in Volume nodes to prevent things like deleting a volume that is being used to create another volume, or attaching a volume that is already being attached. Unfortunately these locks are local to the nodes, which works if we only support Active/Passive configurations, but doesn't on Active/Active configurations when we have more than one node, since locks will not guarantee mutual exclusion of operations on other nodes. We have different locks for different purposes and we will use different methods to allow each of them to handle an Active/Active clusters. List of locks are: - ${VOL_UUID} - ${VOL_UUID}-delete_volume - ${VOL_UUID}-detach_volume - ${SNAPSHOT_UUID}-delete_snapshot Use Cases ========= Operators that have hard requirements, SLA or other reasons, to have their cloud operational at all times or have higher throughput requirements will want to have the possibility to configure their deployments with an Active/Active configuration and have the same behavior they currently have. Proposed change =============== We will modify these 4 locks in 2 different ways. On one hand we have locks that are used to prevent deletion from resources that are being used as the source of a volume creation and on the other we have locks to prevent concurrent operations that need to be queued. Locks that prevent deletion of the source of a volume creation (they are created by ``create_volume`` method: - *${VOL_UUID}-delete_volume* - Used in ``delete_volume`` - *${SNAPSHOT_UUID}-delete_snapshot* - Used in ``delete_snapshot`` For these 2 methods we will add a filter to the conditional update -the one being used to prevent `API Races`_- that will prevent us from deleting a volume or a snapshot that is being used as the source for a volume. We will also add the appropriate response error when we try to delete such a volume/snapshot. Locks that prevent concurrent operations on the same resource: - *${VOL_UUID}-detach_volume* - Used in ``detach_volume`` to prevent multiple simultaneous detaches - *${VOL_UUID}* - Used in ``attach_volume`` to prevent multiple simultaneous attaches For the remaining 2 locks we will implement a locking mechanism on the DB taking advantage of the new table called ``workers`` that has been added by the `HA A/A Cleanup specs`_. We will add a new field called ``method`` to this table. In this new field we will store the current operation (method name) that is being performed on the Volume's manager and it will be used for locking. On ``detach_volume`` and ``attach_volume`` we will add a retry mechanism -same mechanism as locks are using today- and we will retry if the DB already has a record on the DB for the given resource with the current operation. This means that we will only proceed to attach a volume if there is no DB entry for the volume ID with operation ``volume_attach``, and the same will hold true for detaching. To make this atomic, we are using it for mutual exclusion, we will insert the row in the same way we are doing the conditional updates, adding a condition on the insert query to make sure that it only succeeds if no other entry already exists. It is important to notice that timeouts for these new locks will be handled by the cleanup process itself, as rows are removed from the DB when heartbeats are no longer being received, thus releasing the locks and preventing a resource from being stuck. Alternatives ------------ We could use a DLM, which is a stand-in replacement for local locks, but the burden of managing the DLM for cloud operators is too great considering some drivers don't require locks to operate on Active/Active cluster configurations and would not benefit from it. We could also use a similar locking mechanism to the one we are using for attach/detach, using ``workers`` table, to prevent resource deletion instead of adding filters. Data model impact ----------------- Adds a new string field called ``method`` to the ``workers`` table. REST API impact --------------- None Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Very small performance impact from changing local file locks to DB calls. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Gorka Eguileor (geguileo) Other contributors: Anyone is welcome to help Work Items ---------- - Add ``method`` field to ``workers`` table. - Modify cleanup mechanism to add ``method`` field contents and handle multiple entries on ``workers`` table during cleanup. - Add filters to ``delete_volume`` and ``delete_snapshot`` and remove deletion locks. - Add retry mechanism on attach and detach methods using ``method`` field. Dependencies ============ Cleanup for HA A/A: https://review.openstack.org/236977 - We need the new ``workers`` table and the cleanup mechanism. Removing API Races: https://review.openstack.org/207101/ - We need compare-and-swap mechanism on volume and snapshot deletion to be in place so we can add required filters. Testing ======= Unittests for new DB filters. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== General Description for HA A/A: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/232599/ Cleanup for HA A/A: https://review.openstack.org/236977 Removal of API Races: https://review.openstack.org/207101/ .. _HA A/A Cleanup specs: https://review.openstack.org/236977 .. _API Races: https://review.openstack.org/207101/

commit_message:
Fix wrong claim error message

Now when create a claim with a big number, the message is not
correct. It's showing the max TTL of message instead of claim.
This patch fixes it.

Closes-Bug: #1575870

Change-Id: Ia948cc521a48101fa17ec23f49b5b03164f02940
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/zaqar refs/changes/69/310569/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
ceph: allow to deploy python-cradox

python-cradox is a new dependency in Gnocchi when deploying Ceph
backend.
RDO team does not want to handle this dependency because it's too
specific to the Ceph backend, so puppet-gnocchi will be able to deploy
it or not (installed by default).

Usage of puppetlabs-stdlib will allow duplicated resource, also using
the tags will allow to modify the resource.
Adding tests & release note.

Change-Id: I110d1080b2dcf362f4e48a773ceef1e87d68b7cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-gnocchi refs/changes/46/311746/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: it 'installs dependencies' do is_expected.to contain_package('python-cradox').with( :ensure => 'present', :tag => ['openstack', 'gnocchi-package'] ) end context 'with package_ensure set to absent' do before do params.merge!({ :package_ensure => 'absent'}) end it 'uninstall dependencies' do is_expected.to contain_package('python-cradox').with( :ensure => 'absent', :tag => ['openstack', 'gnocchi-package'] ) end end

subject: cephfs_native: Change backend snapshot dir's name
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-06 09:23:51.000000000', 'files': ['manila/tests/share/drivers/cephfs/test_cephfs_native.py', 'manila/share/drivers/cephfs/cephfs_native.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/54cef3d20a5a3768ead886b69052b391c0fd7430', 'message': "cephfs_native: Change backend snapshot dir's name

A snapshot of a share created by cephfs_native driver can be read from
its corresponding snapshot directory created within the share. The
snapshot directory was named using the snapshot instance ID, which
would be visible only to manila admins. In effect, a non-admin manila
user could not identify the snapshot directory (in the mounted share)
from where he could read the snapshot's contents.

Fix by creating ceph snapshot directories with names that also contain
snapshot IDs that are visible to all users.

Change-Id: Ifda0300c60fca87a3f993c1f2eaeb05d1dd909d4
Closes-Bug: #1563198
(cherry picked from commit cbb316babf1648f46c7e31e6415470df29dd5377)
"}]
commit_message:
cephfs_native: Change backend snapshot dir's name

A snapshot of a share created by cephfs_native driver can be read from
its corresponding snapshot directory created within the share. The
snapshot directory was named using the snapshot instance ID, which
would be visible only to manila admins. In effect, a non-admin manila
user could not identify the snapshot directory (in the mounted share)
from where he could read the snapshot's contents.

Fix by creating ceph snapshot directories with names that also contain
snapshot IDs that are visible to all users.

Change-Id: Ifda0300c60fca87a3f993c1f2eaeb05d1dd909d4
Closes-Bug: #1563198
(cherry picked from commit cbb316babf1648f46c7e31e6415470df29dd5377)

commit_message:
Add support for the libvirt/hw_disk_discard option

The Ceph RBD deployment guide for OpenStack [1] suggests use of
hw_disk_discard from Juno. This change adds support into the module
for such a config option.

1. http://docs.ceph.com/docs/master/rbd/rbd-openstack/

Change-Id: Ib0198d63d7e1de4677a1345da1f710277a63d13b
(cherry picked from commit e33acfbe9e24710cbd6c038b9b91871b30c31834)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-nova refs/changes/55/279055/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*libvirt_hw_disk_discard*] # (optional) Discard option for nova managed disks. Need Libvirt(1.0.6) # Qemu1.5 (raw format) Qemu1.6(qcow2 format). # Defaults to $::os_service_default # $libvirt_hw_disk_discard = $::os_service_default, 'libvirt/hw_disk_discard': value => $libvirt_hw_disk_discard;

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/service-types-authority refs/changes/88/286088/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ========================= Service Types Authority ========================= The following is a central authority for handing out service types to projects. An OpenStack Project which has a REST API needs to have a service type registered for itself that guaruntees you are talking to a well known API that is documented. This provides users of a cloud to always know these well known entities mean the same thing. Attributes ========== The following attributes are required for a service type registration project (required) ------------------ A openstack git project that contains the definition of the API claimed by this service type. This is assumed to be a code repository, though if multiple projects are implementing the same API they can choose to have this be an API definition repository instead. api_reference (required) ------------------------ A published API reference document for the API identified by this service type. description (optional) ---------------------- A short description about the service in question. It helps people reading only this document.

commit_message:
Only template /etc/environment when we need to

global_environment_variables is not always defined.
This patch addresses an issue introduced in
I401763d277d179249973545e873796f9dd54049b

Cherry-pick of Ifa7ed380432f60af3c9e68c1bfa2a43dc2d65473

Change-Id: Ifa7ed380432f60af3c9e68c1bfa2a43dc2d65473

subject: updated for lxc-container-create for multi-distro support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-02 17:34:21.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create/commit/e17a138e1cde1111584535d2912dc179c1532eee', 'message': 'updated for lxc-container-create for multi-distro support

This change updates the lxc-container-create role to build lxc containers
using the download template. The build supports ubuntu 14.04/16.04 and
RedHat/CentOS 7 using the multi-distro framework.

This change is incorporating updates built into the lxc_hosts role. Once
merged this should unblock all work geared toward multi-distro support and
testing. The testing structure has been updated to match what is being done
in other roles.

A new file was created "manual-tests.rc" which assists in manual testing
by exporting the needed environment variables to run the role tests without
requiring everything to run through tox which has undesirable side-effects
when running tests that span multiple roles.

Change-Id: Iee304dd026e0865e0444259d2132122233d90f5f

commit_message:
updated for lxc-container-create for multi-distro support

This change updates the lxc-container-create role to build lxc containers
using the download template. The build supports ubuntu 14.04/16.04 and
RedHat/CentOS 7 using the multi-distro framework.

This change is incorporating updates built into the lxc_hosts role. Once
merged this should unblock all work geared toward multi-distro support and
testing. The testing structure has been updated to match what is being done
in other roles.

A new file was created "manual-tests.rc" which assists in manual testing
by exporting the needed environment variables to run the role tests without
requiring everything to run through tox which has undesirable side-effects
when running tests that span multiple roles.

Change-Id: Iee304dd026e0865e0444259d2132122233d90f5f
Depends-On: Ie13be2322d28178760481c59805101d6aeef4f36
Co-Authored-By: Jesse Pretorius <jesse.pretorius@rackspace.co.uk>
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kevin.carter@rackspace.com>

commit_message:
Fix docstring for policy.enforce method

This patch corrects the name of the 'target' parameter and
adds the 'do_raise' parameter in the doc string for the
policy.enforce method.

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ib6000ae868bc91a1aa8504b377408a829f1c9951

commit_message:
Keystone jobs should honor upper-constraints.txt

Some targets don't respect upper-constraints like
cover and releasenotes, so make sure don't use
the same install_command for those jobs.

Change-Id: I8636e7c86c6c5c608429fab88e181108ae615db9
(cherry picked from commit db7bdf9aa0cb0ba5fbae5ae07ecdb9f024213deb)

commit_message:
Role tests should test against the same branch

All dependent roles used in testing must be the same branch as
the role under test.

The py_from_git role is removed as it is no longer required.

Change-Id: I49d2c03124de38789c8fc1fba94ee90aba32c17e

commit_message:
WIP: Objects for trunk resources

Initial commit for versioned objects for VLAN aware VM support.

Note: test changes in-progress.

commit_message:
Change max size validation parameters

username/password authentication mechanism uses "max_param_size"
defaults to 64 to validate the length of inputs such as username but
in the db schema only username is set to 255.

Modifications were made to the validation parameters for username.

Change-Id: I380299e8fdd7a71a4067bbf1b1ac5648b82fc76d
Closes-Bug: #1279750

commit_message:
Manila support in metadata service

A highly sought feature for Manila (the Shared Filesystems service) is for
client VMs to be able to auto-mount file shares that are available to them.
But a Nova instance is generally attached to the tenant data plane, not the
cloud control plane. So there is no way for an instance to invoke Manila
APIs to discover which shared filesystems are available for it to mount.
The Nova metadata service offers an elegant solution to this sticky problem.
By adding an endpoint to the metadata service, code running on a Nova
instance can invoke that to get a list of shares available to that tenant
context.

Change-Id: Ib5dbc8fb82aa701b3e096d60ea5eae038462b278
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/01/248301/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ================================== Manila support in metadata service ================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/manila-support-in-metadata-service A highly sought feature for Manila (the Shared Filesystems service) is for client VMs to be able to auto-mount file shares that are available to them. But a Nova instance is generally attached to the tenant data plane, not the cloud control plane. So there is no way for an instance to invoke Manila APIs to discover which shared filesystems are available for it to mount. The Nova metadata service offers an elegant solution to this sticky problem. By adding an endpoint to the metadata service, code running on a Nova instance can invoke that to get a list of shares available to that tenant context. Problem description =================== The Manila Shared Filesystems project is rapidly growing in OpenStack deployments. It's in several of the largest distributions, and its latest (as of Mitaka.1) adoption metric is 8% [1]. One of the most-requested Manila features is auto-mounting of file shares, whereby any shares that are available to a tenant's instance(s) are automatically discovered and mounted therein. The mount may be accomplished via a cron job, a cloud-init script, or other means. But the hard part is discovering the shares that are available. An instance managed by Nova typically has network connectivity to one or more tenant networks on which it can mount file shares, but it generally has no access to or knowledge of the Manila API service endpoint. So the issue is how to discover the available shares. The Manila auto-mount problem has been discussed at length at multiple OpenStack summits, and as described below there are numerous potential solutions, none of which is applicable to all use cases. One of the simplest solutions is to use the Nova metadata service to proxy requests from instances to the Manila API service to discover available shares. This was prototyped and demonstrated at the Vancouver summit to broad approval by the Manila community. This change to Nova is small. Use Cases --------- * An End User creates a new Nova instance and assigns it an IP address. The User then creates a Manila file share and grants it access to the same address. The share is automatically mounted within the instance. * An End User creates one or more Manila shares and grants access to each share to a whole subnet. The End User builds a cloud application consisting of multiple Nova VMs. The shares created by the User are automatically mounted by the VM instances each time they boot. Proposed change =============== The proposed change has two components: * A Manila client module is added to Nova, similar to how the Cinder and other clients are already present. * A single endpoint (shares.json) is added to the Nova metadata service. Accessing this endpoint calls the Manila client to list shares available to the tenant context making the request. Alternatives ------------ Numerous solutions have been considered for addressing the Manila auto-mount requirement. * Automounter + LDAP * Windows group policy + ActiveDirectory * Windows SysInternals / PsTools * SSH + sudo mount (attach-time only, probably linux/unix-only) * Windows alternative to SSH + Automounter * Zeroconf / Bonjour * Custom agent * Notifications via a Zaqar queue * Hypervisor-mediated attach semantics via VirtFS or vsock The consensus in the Manila community is that none of these is anywhere near universally applicable, so the Manila team prefers to begin with one that would seem to have the most appeal and be most broadly implementable. The solution proposed herein would work for all guest types and require minimal effort by deployers and tenants. Data model impact ----------------- No changes to Nova data objects or database schema. REST API impact --------------- There is no change proposed to the Nova REST API. The change is to the Metadata service REST API, where a new endpoint will be added to return JSON-formatted Manila share info for the tenant context from which the call originates. Consistent with other endpoints, the proposed Metadata service endpoint for Manila shares is 'shares.json'. Code running within an instance could access the endpoint using:: http://169.254.169.254/openstack/latest/shares.json Security impact --------------- The Metadata service will use the standard python-manilaclient to access the Manila API, consistent with how other clients are called from there. The Manila client is integrated with Keystone just as the other clients are. To connect with the Manila API, a Manila user's credentials (not necessarily those of a Manila admin) must be added to the Nova config file. And the cloud admin must give that user access to each of the Manila tenants on which auto-mount services are desired. This isn't seen as a security risk, as that user may be restricted as far as needed using Manila's API policy rules. This change doesn't touch any other sensitive data, does not involve cryptography or hashing, does not require sudo or elevated privileges, does not involve user-provided data (only GET Manila APIs would be proxied), and the standard WSGI throttling mechanism should guard against resource exhaustion attacks. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ This feature merely proxies share info between instances and the Manila API, so it should be computationally inexpensive. A script running in an instance could call the endpoint at boot-time only, or perhaps at some configured interval. Besides the Nova Metadata service, no other Nova components would participate. Other deployer impact --------------------- This feature requires a few Nova config parameters for specifying the Manila user credentials for authenticating with Keystone and the Manila API. These are confined to a [Manila] section and are modeled after similar sections for other projects (Cinder, Neutron, etc.). There would appear to already be opportunity to deduplicate some of those, such as the region name as well as the Keystone details. Using the feature is optional. If the Manila-specific parameters are omitted from the Nova config file, the Metadata service will fail to authenticate with Manila and will return a 400 error to the caller. To use the feature, a deployer can include a script in base images that call the shares.json endpoint at instance boot time and mount any available shares. This would preclude the need for tenants to accomplish the same using cloud-init. Developer impact ---------------- None. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: clintonk Other contributors: None Work Items ---------- * Build and demo prototype (Done in Kilo) * Implement unit tests and anything else required (Mitaka) Dependencies ============ * This feature will use the Manila v2 API introduced in Liberty. Testing ======= Manila already uses a first-party driver based on a Nova instance. So it will be straightforward to add scenario tests to Manila to test this feature. It could also be tested by Nova in the gate, although that would require Manila to also be present; Manila is not part of the integrated gate. Documentation Impact ==================== This feature would be documented in the Nova and Manila Admin Guides. References ========== [1] https://www.openstack.org/software/releases/liberty/components/manila History ======= .. list-table:: Revisions :header-rows: 1 * - Release Name - Description * - Mitaka - Introduced

commit_message:
Job Distribution to support HA A/A

This spec outlines work needed to do job distribution for Active/Active
configurations in cinder.

This is just one of the aspects that are needed to support Active/Active
in cinder.

Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-active-active-support
Change-Id: Ieadf7979262142f03d3f337ea4399c54a2d08c52
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/95/232595/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================================= Cinder Volume Active/Active support - Job Distribution ============================================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-volume-active-active-support Right now cinder-volume service can run only in Active/Passive HA fashion. One of the reasons for this is that we have no concept of a cluster of nodes that handle the same storage back-end. This spec adds the concept of cluster to Cinder and aims to provide a way for Cinder's API and Scheduler nodes to distribute jobs to Volume nodes on a High Availability deployment with Active/Active configuration. Problem description =================== Right now cinder-volume service only accepts Active/Passive High Availability configurations, and current job distribution mechanism does not allow having multiple hosts grouped in a cluster where jobs can be queued to be processed by any of those nodes. Jobs are currently being distributed using a topic based message queue that is identified by the topic `host@gackend` and that's the mechanism used to send jobs to the Volume nodes regardless of the physical address of the node that is going to be handling the job, allowing an easier transition on failover. Chosen solution must be backward compatible as well as allow the new Active/Active configuration to effectively send jobs. In the Active/Active configuration there can be multiple Volume nodes - this is not mandatory at all times, as failures may leave us with only 1 active node - with different `host` configuration values that can interchangeably accept jobs that are handling the same storage backend. Use Cases ========= Operators that have hard requirements, SLA or other reasons, to have their cloud operational at all times or have higher throughput requirements will want to have the possibility to configure their deployments with an Active/Active configuration. Proposed change =============== Basic mechanism --------------- To provide a mechanism that will allow us to distribute jobs to a group of nodes we'll add a new `cluster` configuration option that will uniquely identify a group of Volume nodes that share the same storage backends and therefore can accept jobs for the same volumes. This new configuration option, unlike `host` option, can have the same value on multiple volume nodes, with the only requisite that all nodes that share the same value must also share the same storage backends. Topic queues on cinder-volume will change from having `host@backend` as the name of the queue used to distribute jobs to using `cluster@backend`. It is important to notice that `cluster` option is not a replacement of the `host` option as both will coexist within the service and need to be present. To maintain backward compatibility default value for `cluster` will be the same value as `host` on the node, that way we can be sure that nodes will behave exactly the same after they are upgraded and they will continue getting their jobs from the same topic queue as they were before. One benefit of this solution is that it will be very easy, although not as clean, to change a deployment from Single node or Active/Passive to Active/Active without any downtime. All that is needed is to configure the new node that we want to add to the cluster with the option `cluster` set to the `host` option value that the current node has and configure storage backends in the same way, `host` name should be different though. Heartbeats ---------- With Active/Passive configurations a storage backend service is down whenever we don't have a valid heartbeat from the host and is up if we do. On Active/Active configurations it is down if there is no valid heartbeat from any of the hosts that constitute the cluster, and it is up is there is at least one valid heartbeat. Since we are moving from a 1 to 1 relationship between hosts and services to a n to 1 relationship we will need to make some changes to the DB services table as explained in `Data model impact`_. Each backend will be reporting individual heartbeats and the scheduler will aggregate this information to know which backends are up/down grouping by the `topic` field, which will now be `cluster@backend` instead of `host@backend`. This way we'll also be able to tell which specific nodes are up/down based on their individual heartbeats. We'll also need to update the REST API to report detailed information of the status of the different nodes in the cluster as explained in `REST API impact`_. Other ----- All Volume Nodes periodically report their capabilities to the schedulers to keep them updated with their stats, that way they can make informed decisions on where to perform operations. In a similar way to the Service state reporting we need to prevent concurrent access to the data structure when updating this information. Fortunately for us we are storing this information in a Python dictionary on the schedulers, and since we are using an eventlet executor for the rpc server we dont have to worry about using locks, the inherent behavior of the executor will prevent concurrent access to the dictionary. So no changes are needed there. We should also consider if it's worth the effort of changing all DB fields from ``host`` to ``cluster`` since the former will not be correct anymore. Alternatives ------------ One alternative to proposed job distribution would be to leave the topic queues as they are and move the job distribution logic to the scheduler. The scheduler would receive a job and then send it to one of the hosts that belong to the same cluster and is not down. This method has one problem, and that is that we could be sending a job to a node that is down but whose heartbeat hasn't expired yet, or one that has gone down before getting the job from the queue. In these cases we would end up with a job that is not being processed by anyone and we would need to either wait for the node to go back up or the scheduler would need to retrieve that message from the queue and send it to another active node. An alternative to proposed heartbeats is that all services report using `cluster@backend` instead of `host@backend` like they are doing now and as long as we have a valid heartbeat we know that the service is up. There are 2 reasons why I believe that sending independent heartbeats is a superior solution, even if we need to modify the DB tables: - Higher information granularity: We can report not only which services are up/down but also which nodes are up/down. - It will help us on job cleanup of failed nodes that do not come back up. Although cleanup is not part of this spec, it is good to keep it in mind and facilitate it as much as possible. Data model impact ----------------- We need to split current ``services`` DB table (``Service`` ORM model) to support individual heartbeats and a single service. Modifications to ``services`` table will be: - Change ``host`` field for cluster field - Removal of ``report_count`` field - Removal of ``modified_at`` field since we can go back to using ``updated_at`` field now that heartbeats will be reported on another table. New ``service_heartbeats`` table will have following fields: - ``cluster``: This will be the foreign key that will join with ``services`` table. - ``host``: Primary key. Same meaning as it holds now - ``report_count``: Same meaning as it holds now REST API impact --------------- To report status of services we will add an optional parameter called ``cluster_detail`` which will report the node breakdown. When ``cluster_detail`` is not set we will report exactly as we are doing now, to be backward compatible with clients, and we'll return ``cluster`` field in the place of ``host`` and in ``state`` we'll send if *any* of the hosts forming the cluster are up. When ``cluster_detail`` is set to False, which tells us client knows of the new API options, we will be returning key ``cluster`` instead of key ``host`` and we'll return new fields: - ``nodes``: Number of nodes that form the cluster. - ``down_nodes``: Number of nodes that are down in the cluster. If ``cluster_detail`` is set to True we'll return a field called ``hosts`` that will contain a list of dictionaries with ``state`` and ``host`` keys that will contain individual values for each of the cluster hosts. On the update we should allow to receive ``host`` or ``cluster`` and they will be treated in the same way. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Performance Impact ------------------ Negligible if we implement the aggregation of the heartbeats on a SQL query using exist instead of retrieving all heartbeats and doing the aggregation on the scheduler. Other deployer impact --------------------- This will be backward compatible since we are using current ``host`` value as default for ``cluster``, so only administrators that wish to give cluster names in case they add nodes to the cluster will be have any impact. Not only will they have to add ``cluster`` option to cinder.conf but since we are changing topic queues they will also have to make sure that there are no requests for the nodes on the broker queues and they will probably want to delete old queues after changing to new cluster queues to keep their message broker clean. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Gorka Eguileor (geguileo) Other contributors: Anyone is welcome to help Work Items ---------- - Make DB changes to ``services`` table and add the new ``service_heartbeats`` table. - Add cluster configuration option. - Change topic queue used for job distributions on the API, the Scheduler and the Volume nodes. - Modify Scheduler code to aggregate the different heartbeats. - Change API's index response as well as the update. - Update cinder-client service-list to support new boolean argument ``--cluster-detail`` Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unittests for new API behavior. Documentation Impact ==================== This spec has changes to the API as well as a new configuration option that will need to be documented. References ========== None

commit_message:
Update requirements to fix tosca-parser to 0.4.0

- Updated requirements.txt to pin tosca-parser and heat-translator
  to 0.4.0 to prevent breakage when the 0.5.0 release of tosca-parser
  comes out.  Need 0.5.0 of heat-translator to fix breakage caused by
  0.5.0 of tosca-parser

Change-Id: I1a66fce3281234a64da45a72d3573caeed7d0dd4
Closes-Bug: 1577807

commit_message:
Update docs to use the latest image link

In fedora people, we created a link to the latest image:
https://fedorapeople.org/groups/magnum/fedora-atomic-latest.qcow2.
Currently, this link is pointed to
https://fedorapeople.org/groups/magnum/fedora-23-atomic-20160405.qcow2.
It should be updated when a new image is uploaded. For now,
we need to update our docs to point to the new link.

Partial-Bug: #1573361
Change-Id: I8ff21a3372a929511351f5242568729d07b6e26b

subject: stadium: exercise the inclusion criteria
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-18 05:00:24.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/8f68a8d702bf66a0a5772c88fbeb00c9a3fc8775', 'message': "stadium: exercise the inclusion criteria

As PTL, I chose to follow up with a single patch to express
my position on the remainder of the projects that are currently
listed under Neutron. I do not expect an overwhelming agreement,
but I imagine that no uproar will happen either.

I believe that all circumstances considered, and the feedback
collected so far, this is the best outcome we can reach
considered where the project is coming from, where it is, and
where it is heading.

Having said that, nothing is carved in stone. As interest in
some projects changes over time, the list may as well change
during its course.

Drum roll begin....let's have it!

Change-Id: Id0e091858a253ae62afdb2f435b53bcafd3efff0
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-18 17:50:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/cc1ddc9fea25fcedc2f3704d6fbdc118176893df', 'message': "stadium: exercise the inclusion criteria

my position on the remainder of the projects that are currently
listed under Neutron. I do not expect an overwhelming agreement,
but I imagine that no uproar will happen either.

I believe that all circumstances considered, and the feedback
collected so far, this is the best outcome we can reach
considered where the project is coming from, where it is, and

Having said that, nothing is carved in stone. As interest in

during its course.

for governance reasons has clearly gotten out of hand, and
