commit_message:
stadium: exercise the inclusion criteria

The current state of things is broken. Having the PTL or his/her
proxies blissfully approve projects for inclusion in Neutron
for governance reasons has clearly gotten out of hand, and
has the danger of diluting the value and the sense of team
collaboration that this project took years to build.

Neutron team has worked hard to provide a pluggable framework
and plugins that allowed it to experiment and validate such a
pluggable framework. Network services and initiatives are not
automatically entitled to be 'labelled' as Neutron if they
simply use the pluggable framework.

Change-Id: Id0e091858a253ae62afdb2f435b53bcafd3efff0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/28/281628/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | Name | Functionality | Release | +===============================+=======================+==============+ | neutron_ | base,l2,ml2,core,l3 | Folsom | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | neutron-lbaas_ | lb,dashboard | Grizzly | | neutron-lbaas-dashboard_ | | Liberty | | octavia_ | | Liberty | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | neutron-fwaas_ | fw | Havana | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | neutron-lib_ | base | Mitaka | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | networking-odl_ | ml2,l3,lb,fw | Icehouse | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | networking-ovn_ | core | Liberty | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | neutron-vpnaas_ | vpn | Havana | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | python-neutronclient_ | client | Folsom | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+ | python-neutron-pd-driver_ | pd | Liberty | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+--------------+| dragonflow_ | core | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+| networking-bagpipe_ | ml2 | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+ | networking-bgpvpn_ | vpn || networking-calico_ | ml2 | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+| networking-l2gw_ | l2 | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+| networking-midonet_ | core,ml2,l3,lb,fw | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+| networking-odl_ | ml2,l3,lb,fw | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+ | networking-ofagent_ | ml2 | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+ | networking-onos_ | ml2,l3 | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+| networking-sfc_ | sfc | +-------------------------------+-----------------------+**Q: Why are Networking-l2gw and Networking-sfc not included under Neutron?** These projects were created with the intent of unblocking a stalemate that lasted for years. Layer 2 gateways and traffic steering were initiatives that were unable to progress in the context of the Neutron core for a number of reasons, and as soon as the opportunity of out-of-tree pluggable extensions was opened up, the opportunity was siezed, and we let code talk. Even though some Neutron contributors have been involved since the inception (the PTL for Mitaka included), the projects are still gaining momentum, but the lack of deep involvement from the the Neutron team makes it hard to justify the inclusion during the Mitaka timeframe. **Q: Why is Dragonflow not included under Neutron?** Initially an alternative way to distributed routing, this initiative grew to become a major provider of network services. None of the key contributors to this project have a track record development with Neutron and the rest of Neutron services. It can be considered a suitable alternative to some other Neutron building blocks, but that does not justify the inclusion based on the aforementioned criterion. **Q: Why is Networking-bagpipe/bgpvpn not included under Neutron?** With greater interest in advanced L3 use cased, like bgp dynamic routing, it is possible that more Neutron contributors could become involved with bagpipe/bgpvpn and the project could be considered for inclusion. Until then, it is safe to assume that this should not be included during the Mitaka timeframe. **Q: Why is Networking-calico not included under Neutron?** This project is adopting a pure layer 3 approach to virtual networking and it is being instrumental in helping the Neutron core framework to revise some of the API constructs, and fundamentals underpinning the Neutron networking model. This is an initiative mainly driven by Metaswitch which, like Astara/Akanda and others, are trying to monetize open source to deliver value in cloud environments. There is no ground to justify its inclusion. **Q: Why is Networking-midonet not included under Neutron?** Midonet used to be a proprietary technology developed by Midokura. **Q: Why are Networking-odl and Networking-ovn included under Neutron?** OpenDaylight is seen by some as a sister project to OpenStack. The SDN controller based approach is alternative to providing network virtualization and high level network services in cloud environments. OpenDaylight has been in the minds of some Neutron contributors since its inception back in the Icehouse days. Like OVN, which is a younger attempt to tackling the SDN Controller based approach to network virtualization, OpenDaylight integrates with Open vSwitch, which is a key component of the Neutron stack. As of Mitaka, both projects are still considered relevant initiatives within the Neutron project, assumed that Neutron contributors continue to actively support the efforts. **Q: Why is Networking-ofagent not included under Neutron?** This project is the process of being deprecated in favor of the ML2 OVS driver using native OpenFlow integration. **Q: Why is Networking-onos not included under Neutron?** Onos is yet another open source SDN controller. Even though some may consider ONOS complementary to OpenDaylight, it is still early to say whether the Neutron team should have an interest in another SDN Controller based approach. Because of lack of team overlap, this project is not considered for inclusion during the Mitaka timeframe.

commit_message:
iPXE: retry on failure during introspection

Ensure iPXE retry to boot from the network in case of failure.
--timeout is required to avoid an unlimited freeze, the goto loop is
here to force iPXE to retry the download. imgfree ensure the image get
clean.

References:
 I0fbb40c711a707ae9fae186e9afbe62b79168e28
 I472dfb73044df50849c9cf72de90e59151698376
 Issue: #1326656

Change-Id: I6782f6499a8a8a9706415b3c9b22d41a9abb2e30

commit_message:
Check active vios before destory

Closes-Bug:1575486
Before destroy check for active vios list. If active vios is there then only proceed with destroy

commit_message:
Prevent nova-api from dying if enabled_apis is wrong

This prevents nova-api from dying if there are values in
``enabled_apis`` which don't actually exist.

Closes-Bug: #1572495

Change-Id: Id9a6f5e38b017f4687eb245fd238104379d437d6

commit_message:
Combine pip_install and pip_lockdown roles

Since lockdown is really just a form of specific pip
configuration and since the pip_install role already does
some pip configuration, it seems logical and desirable for
these functions to take place in the same role.

This change should pave the way for a simplification of
role dependencies and the removal of explicit pip_lockdown
role usage with various playbooks that will already have a
dependency on pip_install.

Change-Id: Ia0fc276c2b501f16d4acf73bbbcad6f80804628e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-pip_install refs/changes/29/306529/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Handle exception case with only target_portals

Prior to this if a backend had reported only target_portals and left
out the target_portal option the exception handling would break. To
support this we will just check first and then use a more tailored
exception.

Change-Id: I528e05ae88938a3acc6715e25cb4719dca3eed10
Closes-Bug: #1577601

commit_message:
Adding tox support for bandit

Bandit is a code linter which is used to help identify potential
security vulnerabilities. As part of the plan to integrate bandit
into each OpenStack project, support for a tox testenv is step one.
This incorporates the latest release of bandit, v1.0.1. Gate tests
will also be incorporated later.

Change-Id: I20c8014520e0afbe687782251790bb256e15b7bb

commit_message:
[Verify] Don't install Tempest when `rally verify start`

Rally shouldn't install Tempest when we execute `rally verify start`
because user should explicitly install Tempest with one of the two methods:
1. install a local copy of the project, providing the path to it;
2. use some link to the project.

Also, some log messages were moved to more suitable places and some messages
were added for better logging.

Change-Id: I8b2f819482fd548c8875afb77a307f8389bd6229

commit_message:
Use oslo.log library instead of system logging module

The constants of log levels were added in the 1.8 version of
the oslo.log library. So we can replace all usage of system
logging module with log module from oslo.log.
Also the tempest has lots of modules with the declaration of
LOG variable but doesn't use them. Remove unused LOG variables.

Change-Id: Id757e223b0a15188d5c97f935dcb8f5a666f161a
Closes-Bug: 1481370

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-03 13:29:16.000000000', 'files': ['nodepool/nodepool.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/13b0301ce1a65feb0236264c6e3119568acd28ee', 'message': "Don't configure a mirror for tripleo-centos-7

We don't have an AFS mirror in tripleo-test-cloud-rh1 yet, so we
cannot bootstrap our jenkins slaves to use it.

Change-Id: Ic0eacb8cb8a4359300e3dd3b5d221b95644a6777
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Don't configure a mirror for tripleo-centos-7

We don't have an AFS mirror in tripleo-test-cloud-rh1 yet, so we
cannot bootstrap our jenkins slaves to use it.

Change-Id: Ic0eacb8cb8a4359300e3dd3b5d221b95644a6777
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Amend resource-providers database schema

Makes a number of changes to the proposed resource-providers blueprint
database schema:

- Adds resource_providers.generation field along with lengthy
explanation as to the necessity of this field in compare-and-update
claim logic
- Adds resource_providers.name field to be used with
generic-resource-pools feature
- Adds can_host field to help in future scheduler work

Change-Id: Id875d46222d65f84df8b87a629005f326d15c26b
blueprint: resource-providers
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova-specs refs/changes/53/283253/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: uuid CHAR (36) NOT NULL, name VARCHAR(200) NOT NULL CHARACTER SET utf8,\ generation INT NOT NULL, can_host INT NOT NULL,The `generation` and `can_host` fields are internal implementation fields that respectively allow for atomic allocation operations and tell the scheduler whether the resource provider can be a destination for an instance to land on (hint: a resource pool never can be the target for an instance). INDEX (resource_provider_id, resource_class_id, used),The process of claiming a set of resources in the `allocations` table will look something like this:: BEGIN TRANSACTION; FOR $RESOURCE_CLASS, $REQUESTED_AMOUNT IN requested_resources: INSERT INTO allocations ( resource_provider_id, resource_class_id, consumer_id, used ) VALUES ( $RESOURCE_PROVIDER_ID, $RESOURCE_CLASS, $INSTANCE_UUID, $REQUESTED_AMOUNT ); COMMIT TRANSACTION; The problem with the above is that if two threads run a query and select the same resource provider to place an instance on, they will have selected the resource provider after making a point-in-time view of the available inventory on that resource provider. By the time the `COMMIT_TRANSACTION` occurs, one thread may have claimed resources on that resource provider and changed that point-in-time view in the other thread. If the other thread just proceeds and adds records to the `allocations` table, we could end up with more resources consumed on the host than can actually fit on the host. The traditional way of solving this problem was to use a `SELECT FOR UPDATE` query when retrieving the point-in-time view of the resource provider's inventory. However, the `SELECT FOR UPDATE` statement is not supported properly when running MySQL Galera Cluster in a multi-writer mode. In addition, it uses a heavy pessimistic locking algorithm which locks the selected records for a (relatively) long period of time. To solve this particular problem, applications can use a "compare and update" strategy. In this approach, reader threads save some information about the point-in-time view and when sending writes to the database, include a `WHERE` condition containing the piece of data from the point-in-time view. The write will only succeed (return >0 rows affected) if the original condition holds and another thread hasn't updated the viewed rows in between the time of the initial point-in-time read and the attempt to write to the same rows in the table. The `resource_providers.generation` field enables atomic writes to the `allocations` table using this "compare and update" strategy. Essentially, in pseudo-code, this is how the `generation` field is used in a "compare and update" approach to claiming resources on a provider:: deadlock_retry: $ID, $GENERATION = SELECT id, generation FROM resource_providers WHERE ( <QUERY_TO_IDENTIFY_AVAILABLE_INVENTORY> ); BEGIN TRANSACTION; FOR $RESOURCE_CLASS, $REQUESTED_AMOUNT IN requested_resources: INSERT INTO allocations ( resource_provider_id, resource_class_id, consumer_id, used ) VALUES ( $RESOURCE_PROVIDER_ID, $RESOURCE_CLASS, $INSTANCE_UUID, $REQUESTED_AMOUNT ); $ROWS_AFFECTED = UPDATE resource_providers SET generation = $GENERATION + 1 WHERE generation = $GENERATION; IF $ROWS_AFFECTED == 0: ROLLBACK TRANSACTION; GO TO deadlock_retry; COMMIT TRANSACTION; * - Mitaka (M3) - Added name, generation and can_host fields to the `resource_providers` table
deleted_lines: uuid VARCHAR (64) NOT NULL, INDEX (resource_provider_id, resource_class_id),

commit_message:
Remove the useless nova_ssh configure in the passwords.yml

The nova_ssh_private_key and nova_ssh_public_key is useless, and
they should not be merged.

Change-Id: I7e7178398242060a78fe7caee6e14fa77f2ffe35
Closes-Bug: #1576199
(cherry picked from commit 9318b93c73355e2c58a9f0ac5fff0a17c7aaa0f0)
